author: potuz
content: Yeah I new the tries are different but I didn't imagine that we would share the same object names with different meanings

author: potuz
content: The first time we were debugging interop we wasted hours thinking we had a bug getting a different hash than Nethermind. When we figured this out I imagined that the only shared name was in the inner structure (that is withdrawal_root or transactions_root, but not also on the execution_payload_header... I assumed that the term execution_payload to refer to a "block" was CL terminology)

author: etan_status
content: the problem I raised is that there is `CL ExecutionPayloadHeader` vs `EL block header` ‚Äî they have some fields that are named the same but mean different things. similar to what you mean. the other nice trap in there is that EL withdrawal objects are in wei while CL withdrawal objects use gwei üôÇ

author: etan_status
content: The context for me is that it is impossible to get from `CL ExecutionPayloadHeader` to an `EL block header`, and that clients with access only to `CL ExecutionPayloadHeader` cannot validate proofs w.r.t. the `EL block header`'s hexary `txs_root` and `withdrawals_root`

author: builder_benny_figment
content: Hey, sorry, but is there not a sense of any withdrawal queue? Given the max of 16 withdrawals per payload, would have assumed that there would be some sort of queue (in the sense that folks that have been waiting to withdraw the longest get higher priority than a more recent request)

author: g11tech
content: its a round robin queue implemented simply by keeping track of `nextWithdrawalValidatorIndex` in state

author: radekkapka
content: Hey guys, do we have a user-friendly name for `BLSToExecutionChange`?

author: radekkapka
content: Something that we can uniformly use in our docs and tooling

author: jgm
content:
Trouble with something like that is that it isn't specific enough; a user is likely to expect that an `update` operation could update an existing execution address to a different one, which isn't the case.

`BLSToExecutionChange` is wordy but precise.
